Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Participation in STEM Higher Education: Industry's Vital Role

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
While women make up 51% of the nation's population and 59% of the workforce (US Census Bureau), they comprise a mere 30% of the technology industry. To keep the United States workforce competitive, particularly in the advanced technology industries, increasing the diversity of the workforce is crucial. STEMconnector® is a consortium of over 150 corporations, educational institutions, non-profit organizations and government entities concerned with STEM education and the future of human capital. With a particular emphasis on diversity and women, STEMconnector® targets stakeholders across the STEM spectrum who are passionate about educating and retaining the STEM workforce critical for driving the economy. STEMconnector® will host a workshop in September 2016 to facilitate the sharing of ideas surrounding broadening participation of women in ATE-related fields, especially entry-level technical jobs. This convening will bring together STEMconnector® members and members of the ATE community that actively work on increasing the diversity of the entry-level technical workforce. From the ATE Community, these include the Materials Science Education Support Center, the Regional Center for Next Generation Manufacturing and the National Institute for Women in Trade, Technology and Science (IWITTS).

According to a Gallup study, while 96 percent of Chief Academic Officers rate their institution as either very or somewhat effective at preparing students for the world of work, only 11 percent of business leaders strongly agree graduating students have the skills and competencies that their business needs. This workshop will provide an opportunity for stakeholders from various ATE industry sectors such as manufacturing, agriculture and IT, to directly communicate with the decision makers from ATE-focused colleges and universities. Not only will participating institutions have the platform to share their best practices for what is currently working, but they will also be able to collaborate to form new diversity strategies and build partnerships through connections made at the workshop. Through this workshop, STEMconnector® ultimately aspires to advance women in ATE entry-level jobs through increased recruitment and retention.

The best practices shared and knowledge gained from this workshop will be widely disseminated through web access and print publications. The participating stakeholders will also share these ideas at their respective institutions by implementing action items to improve the diversity programs and strategies currently in place. The compiled resources will provide ATE and STEMconnector® members with tools to refine their outreach and retention strategies, and support women and other students with increased opportunities to succeed in entry-level advanced technology jobs. It is anticipated that the resources will also have the potential to impact women and other students who previously may not have thought of advanced technology industries as a viable career path.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On Wednesday June 28, 2017 STEMconnector hosted the National Science Foundation (NSF) and Million Women Mentors workshop: “Broadening Participation in STEM Higher Education: Industry’s Vital Role.” The goal of the workshop was to engage in conversation about the barriers women face while pursuing Advanced Technological Education (ATE) and discuss best practices about how to recruit and retain more women in ATE. Increasing the number of women in ATE and STEM fields will develop a more diverse and competitive global workforce.

The workshop featured an array of keynote speakers from industry and postsecondary backgrounds: Dr. Beverly Tarulli, Vice President of Human Capital Strategy and Workforce Analytics at PepsiCo; Donna Milgram, Executive Director of the National Institute for Women in Trades, Technology and Science; and Dr. Joan Ferrini-Mundy, Chief Operating Officer at NSF. The speakers shared research about women in STEM and highlighted the success of programs at their organizations that increase the participation of women in a skilled technical workforce.

In addition to the three keynote speakers, STEMconnector also hosted female students who discussed some of the barriers they had faced and tried to overcome while pursuing STEM degrees and careers. Throughout the day, attendees participated in small and large breakout groups. During the first working session, workshop attendees brainstormed the primary motivators and drivers for female students to become involved in STEM. The second working session encouraged attendees to discuss the potential barriers women and minorities face while entering technical fields and how industry and postsecondary institutions can help students overcome the barriers. Inviting attendees from industry and postsecondary enabled both groups to learn from one another and fostered collaboration between the two groups, an essential aspect of improving female recruitment and retention in STEM fields.

To synthesize the presentations and conversations of the workshop and deliver the results, STEMconnector created a whitepaper about the recruitment and retention of women in ATE and STEM fields. The whitepaper outlines the barriers women face while pursuing ATE that were discussed during the workshop, a few of which include social and familial pressure, teacher and professor biases, and low self-efficacy. The whitepaper then provides 10 best practices for postsecondary and industry to utilize to improve female recruitment and retention in ATE and STEM fields. Some of the best practices include increasing girls’ career awareness in middle school and high school, offering experiential learning opportunities to postsecondary female students, creating partnerships between employers and two-year institutions, fostering mentoring relationships between female STEM professionals and female students interested in STEM fields, and implementing pair programming in computer science courses. The intended purpose of the workshop and whitepaper is to contribute to the participation and success of women in ATE and other STEM fields.
